title: Gaetano Rossi
text:
Gaetano Rossi (; 18 May 1774 – 25 January 1855) was an Italian <a href="opera">opera</a> <a href="libretto">librettist</a> for several of the well-known "<a href="bel%20canto">bel canto</a>"-era composers including <a href="Gioachino%20Rossini">Gioachino Rossini</a>, <a href="Gaetano%20Donizetti">Gaetano Donizetti</a>, and <a href="Saverio%20Mercadante">Saverio Mercadante</a> in Italy and <a href="Giacomo%20Meyerbeer">Giacomo Meyerbeer</a> in one of his early Italian successes. Other composers with whom he worked included <a href="Simon%20Mayr">Simon Mayr</a>, a composer and Donizetti's teacher, as well as the prolific <a href="Giovanni%20Pacini">Giovanni Pacini</a>.
Biography.
Born in Verona, Rossi was writing religious verse by the time that he was 13 years old. He wrote libretti for about 60 years, beginning in 1797 with mostly <a href="farsa">farsa</a>s. Rossi wrote the texts for some significant operas by the well-known composers of the era. These included "<a href="Tancredi">Tancredi</a>" and "<a href="Semiramide">Semiramide</a>" for Rossini and "<a href="Il%20crociato%20in%20Egitto">Il crociato in Egitto</a>" for Meyerbeer, as well as later operas for Donizetti such as "<a href="Maria%20Padilla">Maria Padilla</a>" (as co-author) and "<a href="Linda%20di%20Chamounix">Linda di Chamounix</a>". In addition to his writing, he also worked for a time as the <a href="stage%20director">stage director</a> for the <a href="Teatro%20Filarmonico">Teatro Filarmonico</a> in Verona. <a href="Musicologist">Musicologist</a> John Black regards him as producing crude versification, "but nevertheless he had an eye for dramatic situations and his texts, if long-winded, were effective." His success was twofold: in finding mostly foreign sources to utilize as well as introducing "strongly romantic plots to the Italian stage".
